body: This address https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-13
@yingdachen Why is there a DLL added? Wouldn't it be better to just have the sources?
we need to also update the .net code. and this updated dll (not added) reflects those changes.
OK. I am pretty sure this won't fly come release time, though. We can only have open source dependencies at that time.

@markusweimer I made some changes.
- UriSpecification : /reef-example-scheduler
- New APIs added : submit/list/status/cancel/clear

Would you take a look and point me out what I could improve?
This PR also addresses https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-25.
This PR could be split into two: (1) Add the new functionality and (2) use it. I suggest we do it that way to simplify the discussion.
I will split this PR into three to separate functions for easy review and track.
@markusweimer Could I get a chance to have your feedback for the last changes? Thanks in advance.
@yunseong Sorry about that. I was at a conference the last two days and did not have time to look into this. I will do so tomorrow morning (PST)
Oh, don't worry. I was just curious because there has been no answer to the mention :) Thank you Markus.

With the exception of the missing `synchronized` and the future use of [REEF-34](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-34), this looks good to be merged.

A next step could be to expand this to use more than one Evaluator. That way, we can have an example for that as well. But that shouldn't stop this from making it in.

I have a question regarding the `LogParser` class. this is needed because we write the timings to the normal log, correct? Wouldn't it make our life a lot easier if we were writing the timings to a separate log? Or does that make debugging harder? We can always write it to two different logs: The normal one and an additional one for timings which is already in friendly CSV format or such.

It can share the same log file as we can always parse the log file to pick those lines out since those lines follow a special format. 

When the log file becomes bigger, agree, we should separate it from other logs and write it into another file. We used to call it perfLog in my previous projects. perfLogs can be huge each day that need to be processed using Cosmos usually.

I would suggest we have a separate work item for it.

Added test cases for Logging scope
Add interface for LoggingScope and rename original one to ReefLoggingScope
Added comments for new methods
Make ReefLogging Scope injectable. However, it is not necessarily to inject it as the cost might be high.
I addressed the issues raised. @jwang98052 Can you have another look?
All the review comments have been addressed. Can you review again?
The issues raised are addressed.

I left some more comments. More broadly speaking, I have a few comments / missing features:
- We need to be able to choose the log level for these messages. Especially for long running jobs, the size of the log can otherwise be overwhelming.
- Once we have these log levels set, an optimization would be to create a dummy `LoggingScope` for when there would not be a log written. That instance would just do nothing in its constructor or `close()` method to conserve some CPU cycles.
@yunseong In case the prior message wasn't clear: We are ready to merge this with the one minor change. I can do that during the merge, if you want.

Good point. I added logLevel variable in LoggingScopeFactory. It defaults to Level.FINE. User can set it through setLogLevel(). This logLevel is passed to LoggingScope for log. If the Log Level is lower than the level set for the system, the LoggingScope will not really log to a file. That would save the time.

Rename ReefLoggingScope to LoggingScopeImpl
Allow to set log Level for LoggingScope
Address other review comments
Update tests accordingly
@markusweimer It is fine for me to wait until #11 to be merged and apply the changes in this branch. Thank you!

discussions that occur in Github. :(

All review comments are addressed.

the external constructor discussion seems to have gone side-ways :-(

I was thinking we could make a named parameter of type string which is then bound by the user to one of the log levels. We then use that string in an external constructor for `Level` via the method Bryan suggested.

It’s doable. There are a few ways to do it:

User provides external constructor. In newInstance() method, user return a log level he wants like return Level.INFO;  In this way, user need to provide external constructor and bind it to the ConfigurationBuilder when he is using LoggingScopeFactory. 

Reef provides external constructor and make log level as a named parameter string for the user to bind as Markus suggested. In the newInstance() of the external constructor, we just need to return Level.parse(logLevelName); User still needs to bind the external constructor or we provide a getConfigurationBuilder method with bound external constructor for the user to use. 

Simply use String for logLevel as a named parameter used the LoggingScopeFactory constructor. We can then use parse() method to convert the string into Level object.

> Simply use String for logLevel as a named parameter used the LoggingScopeFactory constructor. We can then use parse() method to convert the string into Level object. 

That looks like the easiest way to do it. Let's do that.
Use String for logLevel as a named parameter in LoggingScopeFactory constructor. Change pushed in and review comments are addressed.
Please update your branch with the current apache master. I get merge conflicts on my end when trying to merge them.
Addressed review comments, merged from apache master.

I just noticed the commit message is wrong. This is for REEF-38, not REEF-36

@jwang98052 I have a general question: is `HttpServerReefEventHandler` meant to work across different RMs?

Going off of my local log files, this version probably only works on local: "stderr.txt" won't work for YARN, because logs get output to "driver.stderr". (I don't see why local and YARN have to have different filenames.)

@dafrista They shouldn't have different file names. If they do, than that is a bug :-(

The class `REEFFileNames` has methods that return the name for the driver's stdout and stderr, `getDriverStderrFileName()` and `getDriverStdoutFileName()` which _should_ be used when forming a command line.
Cool, it is injectable. I will replace to use it.
@markusweimer `org.apache.reef.runtime.local.process.RunnableProcess` doesn't use `REEFFileNames`. I'll file an issue.

Thanks @jwang98052 for the comments. I addressed them.

@jwang98052 Did you have a chance to do YARN e2e testing as well? From my local YARN (running on Mac OS X) I get the following NoSuchFileException when trying to retrieve the logfile:

```
Nov 20, 2014 10:40:22 AM org.apache.reef.webserver.JettyHandler handle
INFO: JettyHandler handle is entered with target: /reef/v1/logfile 
Nov 20, 2014 10:40:22 AM org.apache.reef.webserver.JettyHandler handle
INFO: calling HttpHandler.onHttpRequest from JettyHandler.handle() for Reef.
Nov 20, 2014 10:40:22 AM org.apache.reef.webserver.HttpServerReefEventHandler onHttpRequest
INFO: HttpServerReefEventHandler in webserver onHttpRequest is called: /reef/v1/logfile
14/11/20 10:40:22 WARN mortbay.log: /reef/v1/logfile?filename=driver.stderr
java.nio.file.NoSuchFileException: driver.stderr
    at sun.nio.fs.UnixException.translateToIOException(UnixException.java:86)
    at sun.nio.fs.UnixException.rethrowAsIOException(UnixException.java:102)
    at sun.nio.fs.UnixException.rethrowAsIOException(UnixException.java:107)
    at sun.nio.fs.UnixFileSystemProvider.newByteChannel(UnixFileSystemProvider.java:214)
    at java.nio.file.Files.newByteChannel(Files.java:317)
```

I'm wondering if this is a general YARN problem or with this particular setup.
Can you find the file in your test environment?

Yes, ironically I'm getting the `FileNotFoundException` log for
driver.stderr, in my driver.stderr.

The code's open assumes driver.stderr is in the working directory, but it
seems like it's not the right directory for Yarn. For Local, log directory
== working directory so it works.

On Thu, Nov 20, 2014 at 10:53 AM, Julia Wang notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Can you find the file in your test environment?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/pull/15#issuecomment-63749024.

From `YarnJobsubmissionHandler`:

``` java
final List<String> launchCommand = new JavaLaunchCommandBuilder()
[...]
      .setStandardOut(ApplicationConstants.LOG_DIR_EXPANSION_VAR + "/" + this.filenames.getDriverStdoutFileName())
          .setStandardErr(ApplicationConstants.LOG_DIR_EXPANSION_VAR + "/" + this.filenames.getDriverStderrFileName())
          .build();
```

I believe we need to do that such that the yarn logging infrastructure can find the files. One way to deal with this issue is to have the runtimes bind a named parameter that points to the log files. That way, we can use the value of that named parameter to find the logs, regardless of runtime.

Discussed with Markus, we would like to propose a solution that is to define an interface like LogFiles which contains two APIs getStderrFile() and getStdoutFile(). For local runtime, we can implement the interface to return the file names. For yarn, we need to figure out how to get the log file location at run time provide an implementation as well.  Then the http reef handler can just get the file location + files names from the implementation of LogFiles. 

I opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-48 and https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-49

For now, can we merge the change and let separate PRs to handler the issue?

That sounds good. I'll continue with the merge when I get to my desk.

This is really a minimal change we can use for pushing messages from Task to Driver. 

 The interface is a bit awkward. We have to use both `TaskMessageSource` and `HeartBeatTriggerManager.triggerHeartbeat` to get the work done. :)
@dafrista @yunseong Is this good enough for Surf?

Thanks for the review @markusweimer! I addressed some issues and the changes are
- Change the access level of package-private classes and methods.
- Make classes and fields immutable.
- Wait when there is no evaluators until allocation.

Yes, it looks good to cover the current use case in Surf. In Surf, evaluators try to notify the cache status and the driver updates its metadata. But it could yield a large complexity in case user wants to notify/handle multiple type of events. 

As @bgchun mentioned, it is little bit unnatural to enumerate all the information to send in one TaskMessageSource and trigger the whole message with all the information written in it. Instead, I think it would be more intuitive if user can specify the exact message to notify when he/she wants to trigger the heartbeat. Does it make sense?
I left some minor comments. Next round, we'll merge it :-)

If we want to go back to design discussions, I suggest to do so over on JIRA. This thread only reaches a subset of the REEF developers, I am afraid. I'm happy to merge this as is, but want to make sure we have consensus before doing so.
@markusweimer You are right, I'll do that way. I agree it is good enough to be merged now.

@markusweimer This looks good. I will merge it.
All changes for review comments have been checked in.

I don't understand this well enough yet to merge it. There are a couple of concerns that a solution to the JIRA would have that this doesn't (or I don't see it):
1. Each runtime binds a few things within the Driver Configuration as part of the job submission. See for a (terrifying) example `YarnJobSubmissionHandler.makeDriverConfiguration`. These settings wouldn't be made in the above approach. I think we need an API extension for runtimes that allows us to get a `Configuration` they'd like to have merged into the Driver `Configuration` to address this. If there is an easier way, I am all for it. If not, we should track that as a separate JIRA.
2. The Driver ID is made `Optional` here for syntactic convenience while it in reality is very much `required`. Depending on how we choose to solve this, this will require another PR just for that.
3. The factoring of the code is odd. This isn't a problem with this PR, but with the code it touches. And that code took its choices from the ancient distributed shell example. Given that this is going to be our "clean" story for this for the future, it seems wise to rectify this along the way.

In this PR,  we don’t really refactor the existing bridge Launch and JobClient.  I think it should be in a separate PR. After this PR is updated based on the code review, it ends up two classes, one is DriverConfigCreator which contains main program, the other is DriverConfigBuilder which is mainly for calling serialization and create configuration files. 

This PR is to address issue #54 which has three goals: 

1.Create driver configurations that contain java bindings only. This PR uses the same java bridge configuration data as today and removed those which are set from .Net side. Our clients are using this bridge config when submitting jobs. 
1. Make HttpServer and NameServer config as separate configurations so that clients can decide if they want to merge it instead of hard coded and mandatory
2. Make driver skeleton configuration creation as part of the project build process

We do have a lot to revisit such as what shall we really need to put into Java driver configuration especially for runtime configurations, what parameters that .Net client should bind, etc. I think those can be in separate PRs. This PR is to set up an infrastructure to generate java side configuration for bridge clients. The configuration created by this PR would result in the same bindings as the clients are using today. It doesn’t make things worse but move a step further. We can then look at the binding data in the configuration and improve it. 

Yes, required parameter for driver identifier is still open. As you suggested, we can assign an unique one in JobSubmissionHelper if default value is detected. It is understood we do want to use required parameter to enforce compile time injection error. But for the identifier, if the user doesn’t provide, we assign an unique one, that won’t cause any runtime error anyway, right?
